<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Ek het die handtekeninge van die mense. Dit is &#x2019;n dokument wat vir <span class="col_623-624" refersTo="page_0314"/>ons van die Swartbewussynsorganisasies vertel. Wat s&#x00EA; die persoon wat hierdie dokument in Engeland gaan voorl&#x00EA; het? Hy gee die hele geskiedenis van Swartbewussynsorganisasies in Suid-Afrika en die hele geskiedenis van ons land, en dan s&#x00EA; hy&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">Once it had emerged from the mass popular ferments of cultural educational entertainments and discussion groups of the mid-&#x2019;sixties SASO (South African Students&#x2019; Organization) acted not only to crystallize the ideas of the Black consciousness movement and philosophy, but it became also the main catalysing agent for the formation of other Black conscious movement organizations like the Black Peoples&#x2019; Convention, a political organization, BAWU, (Black and Allied Workers Union) &#x2026;</block>

<p>Dit is nie my woorde nie; ek kwoteer nou hulle mense.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I know that.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Dit lui voorts&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">&#x2026; a Workers Organization and the National Youth organization &#x2026;</block>

<p>En dan gaan hulle aan om te vertel wat die vier hoekpilare van die Swart bewussynsorganisasies is. Hulle s&#x00EA;&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">The whole outlook of the Black consciousness movement is encompassed in four cardinal points. Black means oppressed &#x2026;</block>

<p>Dit maak nou nie saak nie; jy is eenvoudig &#x201E;oppressed&#x201D; al is jy nou mnr. Tshabalala self; jy bly &#x201E;oppressed&#x201D;. Ek haal verder aan&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">The oppressed must stand together, Black solidarity:</block>

<ol>

<li>(3) The Blacks or oppressed should learn to be self-reliant; Black man you are on your own.</li>

<li>(4) Black people who are in the majority should take over power. Power to the people.</li>

</ol>

<p>Dan verwys hulle na hierdie konferensie wat hulle &#x2019;n paar jaar gelede, in 1973, in Lesotho gehou het. Ek haal aan&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">The Black consciousness movement arranged for a conference to be held in Lesotho in June of 1973. At this conference attended by delegates from South Africa, Swaziland, Lesotho, Zimbabwe and Botswana the Black consciousness movement successfully piloted a motion for the formation of SASM (South African Students Movement) and Southern African Students Movements. This was designed to give members of the Black consciousness movement a cover under which they could effectively operate internationally to obtain all the experience and equipment necessary for the prosecution of the liberation struggle at all levels, propaganda, agitation, arms struggle.</block>

<p>Dan gaan hy voort en noem een van die persone wat ek in daardie stadium ingeperk het, &#x2019;n sekere mnr. Tiro, en s&#x00EA;&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">He was the prominent activist.</block>

<p>Maar hy was ingeperk, Meneer, en mag ek hom nie inperk nie! En dan gee hulle vir ons die &#x201E;Black Consciousness Movement Programme&#x201D;. Ek wil nie alles lees nie, Meneer, maar ek dink dit is noodsaaklik dat agb. lede oor hierdie saak ingelig word. Ek lees nou nog uit hulle dokument, Meneer; dit is nie &#x2019;n dokument wat my departement opgestel het nie. Hy s&#x00EA;&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">Under SASM, BCM (the Black Consciousness Movement) has moved its most advanced elements and cadres to operate under the Southern African Students Movement cover, particularly to prosecute the struggle at its intensest and highest levels. This means that BCM wants to counter fascist propaganda in all its aspects and possibly silence it forever. BCM wants to mount such an agitation as will tear down all semblance of fascist law and order. BCM wants violently to smash international and national capitalist economic structures and bourgeois state institutions in South Africa and on their ruins to build a new democratic system where discrimination, oppression exploitation of man by man, will be banned for ever.</block>

<p><span class="col_625-626" refersTo="page_0315"/>Hulle vergas my met die storie van hoe hulle dit wil regkry, en dit is suiwer marxisme. Hulle praat van &#x201E;Black solidarity&#x201D; en in verband met die &#x201E;armed struggle&#x201D; s&#x00EA; hulle die volgende&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">The Black Consciousness Movement is resolutely committed to the liberation of the oppressed masses of Azania by building up a people&#x2019;s army and creating conditions for a people&#x2019;s war against the fascist imperialist oppressors. This will be a long protracted struggle in which the People&#x2019;s Army for the Liberation of Azania will throw combatants, who will not only fight the enemy, but will also have the duty to defend the revolution.</block>

<p>Onder die opskrif &#x201E;Military training&#x201D; s&#x00EA; hulle die volgende&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">The Black Consciousness Movement has adopted a military programme to train the Azanian peoples&#x2019; army. This programme is in the process of accomplishment, in spite on intrigues on the part of imperialists running dogs to sabotage it.</block>

<p>&#x201E;Running dogs&#x201D; is &#x2019;n kommunistiese woord vir verraaiers, d.w.s. hulle eie Swart mense wat met die Wit mense saamwerk. Ek lees verder&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">This programme envisages, besides the ordinary military commando training of the cadres, the transformation of the already country-wide revolutionary study cells into politico-military cells. In other words, these cells will be changed into operational groups to train the masses for conditions of military conflict and for the take-over and exercise of political power.</block>

<p>Wat s&#x00EA; hulle in verband met die &#x201E;political training&#x201D; wat gegee moet word? Ek lees verder&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">The Black Consciousness Movement gives political training to its candidates by exposing them to the classical marxist revolutionary theories and to the many texts which give accounts of the experiences of other people who successfully waged revolutionary struggles.</block>

<p>So kan ek voortgaan om agb. lede in te lig oor hoe hierdie mense besig is om Suid-Afrika te probeer vemietig. Laat my toe om vir agb. lede die jongste inligting te gee, ingeval hulle dink ek praat nou van gister en verlede jaar se &#x201E;dingerasies&#x201D;.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#sutton">

<from>Mnr. <person refersTo="hansard_za">W. M. SUTTON</person>:</from>

<p>Wat is verlede jaar se &#x201E;dingerasies&#x201D;? Wat beteken dit?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Die agb. lid moet maar &#x2019;n bietjie Afrikaans gaan leer. Dit spyt my dat ek hom nie ook &#x2019;n taalles kan gee nie, maar ek gaan probeer om hom nou &#x2019;n ander soort les te gee.</p>

<p>Ons inligting is dat die Black Consciousness Movement ten nouste saamwerk met die African National Congress. Die Black Consciousness Movement is nou nie meer op sigself &#x2019;n strategie vir revolusie nie. Die Republiek kan nou alleenlik vernietig word onder aanvoering van &#x2019;n organisasie met &#x2019;n beplande strategie. In hierdie opsig voldoen die National Liberation Front, een van die nuwe &#x201E;fronte&#x201D;, van die African National Congress aan die behoefte en is daar dienooreenkomstig breedvoerig met die African National Congress saamgewerk. Die Swartbewussynsorganisasies van 1977 moet nou voortgaan met die politieke mobilisasie van die Swart man. Die nuwe organisasies wat nou ontstaan het, byvoorbeeld, die Azanian Peoples&#x2019; Organization, die Black Priests Solidarity Group, South African Black Social Workers Association, Human Rights Congress, South African Teachers&#x2019; Action Committee, Soweto Action Committee, Soweto Students League, Soweto Youth League en die Committee of Ten, sal vir hierdie doel gebruik word.</p>

<p>Gemeenskapsorganisasies moet ook opgebou word en mense moet op elke moontlike manier gemobiliseer word. Hulle s&#x00EA; dat hulle graag nog die volgende organisasies sal wil insluit: die Black People&#x2019;s Convention, wat nog in Londen bestaan, South African Students Organization, Black Community Programmes, National Youth Organization, South African Students Movement en die Black Allied Workers Union. Al hierdie organisasies is deur hierdie Regering verbode verklaar. Meneer, is dit nou vir ons snaaks dat polisiestasies aangeval word deur terroriste, Swart mense vermoor word en dat terroriste nie &#x2019;n flenter omgee wie hulle <span class="col_627-628" refersTo="page_0316"/>aanval nie? Is dit nou vir ons snaaks as ons vir die volk s&#x00EA; dat ons besig is met &#x2019;n stryd waaragter &#x2019;n baie bre&#x00EB; beplanning en doelstelling is om te poog om Suid-Afrika op die knie&#x00EB; te dwing. Ek mag miskien net s&#x00EA; dat ons besig is om hierdie stryd te wen. Ons het nie die volk verkeerd ingelig nie; daar is nie die minste twyfel dat ons hierdie stryd sal wen nie. As regter Steyn verplig was om maatre&#x00EB;ls te neem van hierdie aard om Suidwes-Afrika te beskerm, dan wil ek dit baie duidelik vir u s&#x00EA; dat ek nie hoef te bloos dat ons hierdie maatre&#x00EB;ls op die wetboek vir die beskerming van ons vaderland het nie.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid kla oor artikel 6 van die Wet op Terrorisme wat handel oor aanhoudings van persone. Meneer, dit is mos nie aanhouding sonder verhoor nie. Hier het ons te make met &#x2019;n organisasie wat sy doelstellings op skrif gestel het dat hy homself in selle sal organiseer, en dit inderdaad gedoen het. Kan die agb. lede hulself vir &#x2019;n enkele oomblik indink hoe hierdie selle ontrafel moet word deur die Suid-Afrikaanse Polisie alvorens ons na &#x2019;n hof gaan. Die agb. lid het ewe hoogheilig vir my ges&#x00EA; dat daar &#x2019;n ander land is wat nou besluit het dat hy sy terrorisme onder die gewone geregshowe moet beveg. Dit is egter nie vreemd vir Suid-Afrika nie. Een van ons groot probleme is dat ons hierdie stryd voer met al die wettige hofprosesse waaroor ons kan beskik. Ons het die minimum vryheid van mense weggeneem. Ander volkere neem meer weg en kom tot die besluit dat hulle moet teruggaan tot die gewone geregshowe. Ons het nog nooit eers uit die gewone geregshowe beweeg nie. Die terroriste wat ingevolge artikel 6 aangekla word, word almal voor &#x2019;n hof gebring, &#x00F3;f hy word losgelaat &#x00F3;f hy word aangehou as &#x2019;n getuie totdat daardie hofsaak verby is, en dan word hy ook losgelaat. Dit skep vir ons groot probleme. Ek wil nou vir die agb. lid s&#x00EA; dat ek in my kantoor &#x2019;n verklaring van 35 bladsye het van een van hierdie persone wat ingevolge artikel 6 aangehou was. Op elke bladsy noem hy &#x2019;n klomp name van persone wat saam met hom bedrywig was, of van plekke waarheen hulle moes gaan. Kan u uself voorstel hoe die Suid-Afrikaanse Polisie die betrokkenheid van daardie persone een vir een moet nagaan en uitvind of hulle ook by die organisasie betrokke is. Hulle moet na daardie verafgele&#x00EB; plekke in ons land reis om te gaan soek na dit of dat wat volgens so &#x2019;n verklaring bestaan. Dit is &#x2019;n proses wat maande neem. Dan, wanneer die hofsaak voorkom, word onmiddellik gevra om uitstel van twee tot drie maande&#x2014;waarvoor ek nie die mense blameer nie&#x2014;omdat daardie geweldige klagstaat eers deurgewerk moet word. Dan moet die verdediging nog ook eers al daardie beskuldigdes gaan raadpleeg en hoor wat hulle ter verdediging aanvoer. Dit neem maande en maande in beslag, en dan kla die agb. lid nog hier dat party van die mense aangehou word vir nege maande of &#x2019;n jaar voordat hy in die hof verskyn. Dit is mos nie onnatuurlik nie.</p>

<p>Daar is &#x2019;n gesofistikeerde aanslag teen Suid-Afrika Daar is nie &#x2019;n enkele persoon op Robbeneiland wat nie deur &#x2019;n wettige hof in Suid-Afrika daar geplaas is nie. Dit is almal aangehoudenes ingevolge artikel 6 wat op Robbeneiland sit, en sulke aangehoudenes word aangehou met die oog op &#x2019;n hofsaak. Vroe&#x00EB;r of later word die hofsake gehou &#x2026;</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Usually later. If at all.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Mnr. die Voorsitter, ek sal vir u die statistiek gee.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>What about the hundreds who never get charged?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Volgens die statistiek word meer as 95% van die mense wat aangekla is, skuldig bevind. Die mense wat nie aangekla word nie, is gewoonlik getuies. Ook is daar &#x2019;n geringe persentasie mense wat aan ons inligting verstrek het, wat ons laat loop het. Maar dit is waarvoor die wet daar is. As die polisie agterdogtig is in verband met &#x2019;n diefstal, is hulle geregtig om enige persoon vir 48 uur aan te hou om uit te vind wat so &#x2019;n persoon van die diefstal weet.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Yes, but not for two years.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Maar wat terrorisme betref, kan ons mos nie anders optree as om hierdie selle te probeer oopbreek en sodoende te probeer uitvind wat werklik aangegaan het, en om mense aan te hou terwyl ons voortgaan met die werk nie.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#van_der_merwe">

<from>Mnr. <person refersTo="hansard_za">S. S. VAN DER MERWE</person>:</from>

<p>Die agb. Minister laat amper artikel 6 onnodig klink.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from><span class="col_629-630" refersTo="page_0317"/>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Gedurende 1978 was daar 41 verhore waarvan 4 nog nie afgehandel is nie; 63 persone is in die 37 verhore skuldig bevind en 18 persone is nog voor die hof. Behalwe in drie gevalle was skuldigbevindings in al die ander afgehandelde verhore verkry. Gedurende 1979 was daar 7 verhore waarvan 5 nog nie afgehandel is nie; twee persone is sover skuldig bevind in die twee verhore wat wel afgehandel is en 10 persone is nog voor die hof in die vyf uitstaande verhore. In albei die afgehandelde verhore is skuldigbevindings verkry. As &#x2019;n mens skuldigbevindings kry van &#x2019;n onafhanklike hof, Meneer, hoe kan mense dan beweer dat artikel 6 verkeerd is. Ek kan die argument van die agb. lid vir Houghton verstaan as dit aan die lig gekom het dat mense aangehou word wat nie skuldig bevind is nie.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>But that is so.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Al die mense is onskuldig; die grootste persentasie van die aangehoudenes is onskuldig; ons het &#x2019;n klomp onskuldige mense aangehou!</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Most who were defended were in fact acquitted.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Kom ons kyk na hierdie jongmense, hierdie jongmense met hulle &#x201E;advanced views&#x201D; van wie die agb. lid gepraat het. Sy s&#x00EA; ons is verkeerd, hierdie mense het maar net &#x201E;advanced views&#x201D;. Dit is al wat hulle het.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Don&#x2019;t ban them.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Laat ons net na &#x2019;n paar voorbeelde kyk, Meneer. Op 22 November 1972 het die Hof Mazela skuldig bevind aan oortredings ingevolge die Wet op Terrorisme. By die verhoor het getuies vertel hoe hulle in die Republiek gewerf en na lande so ver as Tanzani&#x00EB;, China, Rusland en Oos-Duitsland gestuur is. Geriewe is verskaf vir hulle vervoer per spoor, pad en lug, en na hulle terugkeer is party van hulle weer duisende myle ver teruggestuur vir &#x2019;n opknappingskursus in kommunistiese lande. Die opleiding wat hulle oorsee ontvang het, het elke aspek van terrorisme ingesluit. Hulle is geleer om plofstowwe te vervaardig en te hanteer, om geboue op te blaas. Hierdie inligting is aan die lig gebring in die hofsaak.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Not against convictions before the court.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Hulle is geleer om br&#x00FA;e en installasies te verwoes, om treine te ontspoor en om landmyne op te stel. Hulle is opgelei in spioenasie, die gebruik van kodes, syferskrif, kameras, onsigbare ink. Hulle het onderrig ontvang in die geskiedenis van die Kommunistiese Party in Rusland, Marxisme in die Sosialistiese revolusie. Op een tydstip was daar &#x2019;n opleidingskamp in Odessa in Rusland. Altesaam 150 kursusgangers uit Suid-Afrika op pad terug in Oos-Duitsland met hulle vervalste paspoorte, bewysboeke, belastingsertifikate ontvang van &#x2019;n Suid-Afrikaanse vrou wat aan hulle bekend gestel is as kameraad Jane.</p>

<p>Mnr. die Voorsitter, dit is nou &#x201E;the young people with advanced views&#x201D;.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Oh rubbish! You know I did not talk about those people. You are giving a distorted view of what I said.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Daar is die saak van Mombaras en Hosey, twee Blanke uitlanders. Vier Suid-Afrikaanse Swart mense het gedurende 1973 in die Hooggeregshof te Pretoria tereggestaan op aanklagte ingevolge die Wet op Terrorisme. Onweerlegbare getuienis vertel van &#x2019;n sameswering om die bestaande orde omver te werp en van &#x2019;n beplande revolusie waarin bloedvergieting, koelbloedige moorde op vroue en kinders onvermydelik sou wees. Die misdade was in die woorde van die regter afskuwelik. Medepligtigheid van Rusland is bewys. Die getuienis het getoon dat die vier Swartes in Rusland opgelei is in terroristebedrywighede en dat Rusland die African National Congress gebruik het om insypelaars in die land te kry en voorbereidings vir &#x2019;n gewelddadige revolusie te tref. Die twee Blankes was samesweerders uit die buiteland. Mombaras is &#x2019;n Australiese burger van Griekse afkoms. Hosey is in Ierland gebore. Albei het voor hulle koms hierheen in Engeland gewoon. Die vier Swartes moes na hulle terugkeer uit Rusland die mense hier organiseer en dan op bevele uit Londen geweldpleging aanhits. Dit is nou die jongmense, Meneer!</p>

<p>Neem byvoorbeeld die lektor, Raymond Suttner, wat op 3 November in die Hooggeregshof <span class="col_631-632" refersTo="page_0318"/>in Durban skuldig bevind is aan misdrywe. Die feite van die saak is dat Suttner die doelstellings van die verbode Kommunisteparty en die African National Congress bevorder het. Hy het opleiding oorsee ontvang en by sy terugkeer in die Republiek duisende vlugskrifte versprei waarin gewelddadige revolusie in die Republiek aangehits word.</p>

<p>So kan ek voortgaan om een hofsaak na die ander as voorbeeld te gee van gruweldade wat beplan is. Maar nou word aan ons vertel dit is almal mense wat ingevolge artikel 6 aangehou is. Dan vra die agb. lid dat ons dit moet afskaf want die meeste van hierdie jongmense het maar net &#x201E;advanced views&#x201D;.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>There is the common law against treason.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Neem byvoorbeeld die sogenaamde Bordergate-saak. Hierdie mense het milit&#x00EA;re opleiding in die buiteland ondergaan, en sekere mense doodgeskiet. Regter Davidson het op die bank inmekaar gesak en is dood. Hierdie ongelukkige verloop het &#x2019;n tweede verhoor genoodsaak waartydens die meeste getuienis <i>de novo</i> gelei moes word. Die beskuldigdes se verdediging is deur verskeie senior advokate behartig. Ses van die beskuldigdes is tot lang tydperke van gevangenisstraf gevonnis.</p>

<p>Neem die geval van Solomon Mahlangu en Mandi Motlung, Angola-opgeleide terroriste wat teruggekom het en by die motorhawe van John Orr sommer summier twee mense doodgeskiet het met &#x2019;n outomatiese Scorpion-masjienpistool. En nou kry ons hierdie soort optrede waar die agb. lid &#x2019;n telegram aan ons stuur waarin sy vra dat die teregstelling nie moet plaasvind nie.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I asked for clemency. Correct.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Maar wat my dronkslaan&#x2014;en dit is die vraag wat ek aan die agb. lid wil stel, Meneer&#x2014;is dat daar op dieselfde dag, so verneem ek, vier of vyf ander mense was wat ook tereggestel moes word en wat inderdaad tereggestel is. Waarom het die agb. lid net vir Mahlangu uitgesoek en &#x2019;n telegram in verband met hom aan my gestuur? Het die ander mense dan nie ook die doodstraf gekry nie? Is die ander mense nie ook op dieselfde dag opgehang nie?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>That was a very different situation.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Hoekom het die agb. lid nie ook daardie mense se vrylating bepleit nie?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>This was a particular case and the hon. the Minister knows it.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Hoekom het sy dit nie gedoen nie? Laat sy vir hierdie Komitee vertel hoekom sy tussen al daardie mense wat tereggestel moes word net daardie een persoon uitgesonder het. Ek sal vir haar s&#x00EA; hoekom sy dit gedoen het, Meneer.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Because his lawyers came to me, firstly and, secondly, I had appealed on his behalf &#x2026;</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Mnr. die Voorsitter, die saak van Solomon Mahlangu is georganiseer deur die Anti-Apartheid Movement van Brittanje. Hulle maak dan gebruik van die linksgesinde mense in Suid-Afrika. En ek s&#x00EA; nie die agb. lid doen dit willens en wetens nie; sy doen dit onwetend &#x2026;</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>But the hon. the Minister knows that his lawyers came to me, and I went to him.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Hulle gebruik die agb. lid om hulle doelstellings te bereik en omdat hulle haar opgesteek het, stuur sy &#x2019;n telegram aan my.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>It has nothing to do with the Anti-Apartheid League. It was his own mother through his lawyers who came to me.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Die agb. lid weet net so goed as ek dat daardie hele besigheid deur die Anti-Apartheid Movement georganiseer was.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Rubbish! Not my part in it at all. I did it entirely off my own bat.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Nou word hier egter aan my &#x2019;n vraag gestel, en dit is &#x2019;n billike vraag. Ek s&#x00EA; nie dit is &#x2019;n onbillike vraag nie. Daar is <span class="col_633-634" refersTo="page_0319"/>aan my gevra: As ons nou moet aanvaar dat dit noodsaaklik is, wat doen jy om mense wat ingevolge artikel 6 aangehou word totdat die hofsaak voorkom, te beskerm? Mnr. die Voorsitter, ek moet daarop wys dat die Wet bepaal dat &#x2019;n landdros hierdie mense elke twee weke moet besoek en hulle kan aan hom klagtes voorl&#x00EA;. Maar omdat die beskuldiging gemaak word dat die landdros &#x2019;n sittende lid en &#x2019;n administratiewe beampte is en aangehoudenes hom nie glo nie, en so meer, het ek verder gegaan en twee afgetrede persone in die private lewe aangestel, twee persone in wie almal in Suid-Afrika vertroue het, en hulle verslae het ek hier by my. Ek wil dus &#x2019;n uitnodiging aan die agb. lid rig om te eniger tyd die verslae van hierdie twee persone, naamlik mnr. Mouton, oud-Hooflanddros van Pretoria en mnr. Willem van den Berg, oud-Prokureur-generaal, te kom besigtig. Mits die agb. lid die privaatheid van hierdie verslae sal respekteer, gee ek aan haar en die Opposisie die reg om na daardie verslae te kom kyk.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I accept your kind invitation.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Mnr. die Voorsitter, ek doen dit om die eenvoudige rede dat ek tevrede is dat die werk wat die twee here doen van so &#x2019;n aard is dat ons enige moontlikheid van intimidasie&#x2014;&#x2019;n mens kan natuurlik nie 100% seker wees nie&#x2014;uitskakel. Meer as dit kan geen Minister ter w&#x00EA;reld doen nie; hulle kan aan my s&#x00EA; net wat hulle wil. Ons het ons uiterste bes in die omstandighede gedoen.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>That was a bit late in the day.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Why?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Because you were 35 deaths too late. That is the reason why.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#pretorius">

<from>Mr. <person refersTo="hansard_za">N. J. PRETORIUS</person>:</from>

<p>Is that what it comes to?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Yes, that is what it comes to. Under sections 6 and 10 under the 90-day law.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Die agb. lid maak nou &#x2019;n beskuldiging wat sy glad nie kan staaf nie en ek ignoreer daardie beskuldiging.</p>

<p>In sy lesing vra adv. De Villiers aan my&#x2014;en ek haal aan&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">Wat was die maatstawe by die inperking en aanhoudings van 19 Oktober 1977?</block>

<p>Meneer, sover ek kan onthou was daar geen inperkings of aanhoudings op daardie dag nie. Daar was wel daardie dag 18 organisasies in die ban gedoen. Nadat verslae oor hulle uitgebring is wat volgens Wet deur &#x2019;n komitee van drie landdroste gedoen is en ek daardie verslae gesien het en omdat dit &#x2019;n reeks organisasies was wat in die ban gedoen sou word, het ek daardie geval drie weke lank in die Kabinet bespreek. Ek wil aan die agb. lid s&#x00EA; dat ek heeltemal tevrede is dat daardie organisasies in die ban gedoen moes word. Trouens, ek hoef dit nie te s&#x00EA; nie en ons kan slegs kyk na die heersende toestand in die land om te besef dat daar &#x2019;n groot mate van vrede bestaan ten spyte van die feit dat daar nog probleme is.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid en die <i>Sunday Times</i> wou van my weet hoekom die uitbetalings van die Staat aan eisers so hoog was. Die agb. lid het dit in die debat genoem en toe hardloop die <i>Sunday Times</i> ook maar weer agterna. Die koerant wou van my weet hoekom daar vanjaar of verlede jaar so &#x2019;n ho&#x00EB; betaling deur die Staat gemaak is aan mense wat die Staat gedagvaar het as gevolg van dinge wat polisiemanne sou gedoen het. Ek wil net &#x2019;n voorbeeld noem. Ek sal die hoogste bedrag neem wat uitbetaal is, nl. R19 566. Dit is &#x2019;n geval van &#x2019;n Swart man wat deur &#x2019;n Swart konstabel agtervolg is weens beweerde roof op &#x2019;n Swart vrou. Hy is noodlottig gewond en die Swart konstabel het lateraan erken dat hy &#x2019;n fout gemaak het met die identifikasie van die Swart man. Dit was &#x2019;n roofgeval en die konstabel het <i>bona fide</i> agter die verdagte aangehardloop, die skoot afgevuur en die verkeerde man geskiet Die Swart konstabel het erken dat hy &#x2019;n fout met die identifikasie van die man begaan het By konsultasie is vasgestel dat die Swart konstabel nalatig was en die eis is betaal. Die oorspronklike eis was R55 500 en R19 566 is uitbetaal.</p>

<p>Ek sal ook &#x2019;n ander geval noem. Ek het gevalle geneem waar ho&#x00EB; uitbetalings gemaak is. Twee Wit konstabels is aangeval deur &#x2019;n klomp Kleurlingmans en hulle was genoodsaak <span class="col_635-636" refersTo="page_0320"/>om te skiet. As gevolg van die aanval is een gedood en twee gewond en daar is &#x2019;n bedrag van R16 000 aan naasbestaandes uitbetaal.</p>

<p>Meneer, in gevalle waar ons wel uitbetaal het, vind ek die volgende. Laat ons nie na die bedrae kyk nie, want ons leef in &#x2019;n tyd van inflasie. Geldbedrae wat toegestaan en bereken word, is baie ho&#x00EB;r as wat dit &#x2019;n paar jaar gelede was. In die jaar 1971 is daar in 141 gevalle bedrae uitbetaal; in 1972, 199; in 1973, 137; in 1974, 35; in 1975, 34; in 1976, 39; in 1977 het die getal tot 69 gestyg, maar dit was nog nie so hoog as di&#x00E9; in 1971 nie, en in 1978 was daar 78 gevalle. Meneer, dit is mos nie die rekord wat die <i>Sunday Times</i> probeer voorhou het dat ons slegs uitbetaal en al hoe meer gedagvaar word nie of dat die bedrae nou hemelhoog is nie. Die bedrae is hemelhoog; die prys van brood is ook hemelhoog! Dit is &#x2019;n feit.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid wou van my weet of daar verdere vervolgings gaan spruit uit die Erasmus-kommissie se verslae. Stel ek dit korrek?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I was referring to the Reynders disclosure.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Meneer, ek het al by vorige geleenthede in die Volksraad ges&#x00EA; dat die Erasmus-kommissie die Polisie gevra het om te wag totdat hulle verslae uitgebring is waarna hulle volstoom kan inspring. Ons het aan die Erasmus-kommissie ges&#x00EA; dat ons &#x2019;n proses aan die gang moet sit om die man uit die buiteland te kry en wou weet of ons intussen &#x2019;n paar van die sake kon ondersoek. Die Polisie het toe die reg verkry om &#x2019;n paar sake te ondersoek waaruit &#x2019;n klag geformuleer is. Die Erasmus-kommissie het egter nou aan die Polisie ges&#x00EA; dat hulle verder kan gaan met ondersoeke. Die agb. lid kan nie vandag aan my kom vra watter vervolgings uit die verslag se bevindinge sal voortspruit nie. Dit is &#x2019;n saak wat baie tyd in beslag sal neem om ondersoek te word. Daar is baie vertakkinge in di&#x00E9; saak en dit sal die Polisie &#x2019;n baie lang tyd neem voordat die handelsafdeling tot &#x2019;n presiese gevolgtrekking kan kom in verband met die bedrywighede van al die mense wat daarby betrokke is.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>But I think you are defeating the ends of justice in regard to Connie Mulder and Van den Bergh.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>To say the least of it, I think that is a silly statement. I am now being kind to you; I could have said a nasty thing.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I am telling you I am quoting senior counsel.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>I am telling you that you can tell senior counsel from me that he knows nothing about investigating a crime.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I will tell him.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Yes, you can do that If he knew how the Police have to investigate crimes, he would not make the statement that this can be done in a few days&#x2019; time&#x2014;if that is the implication of your statement.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#langley">

<from>Mr. <person refersTo="hansard_za">T. LANGLEY</person>:</from>

<p>What senior counsel is the hon. member for Houghton referring to?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>If that is the implication of the statement&#x2026;</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>If you want to know his name I will send it to you.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Die agb. lid wou van my weet wie die koste betaal van die aksie wat ek teen South African Associated Newspapers gehad het.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Wasn&#x2019;t it in the vicinity of R8 000?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>I should like to state quite clearly that the court did not decide that the Government would not be allowed to pay the costs and that I had to pay them. [Interjections.] Let me put it this way. If I have a claim against the hon. member for Houghton and she loses the case, the Black Sash can pay if they so desire. The court does not tell one who has to pay; the court simply gives costs against the respondent. Whoever pays for the costs of the respondent is no affair of the court.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>You mean that I am going to pay the costs out of my taxes?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>It has nothing to do with the court. I want to state that clearly.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from><span class="col_637-638" refersTo="page_0321"/>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>So it is the taxpayer who is going to have to pay.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>I should like to refer to the case <i>P. Pelser</i> v. <i>Barend van Niekerk.</i> My predecessor, Minister Pelser, personally sued Van Niekerk for defamation arising out of an official action taken by my predecessor. The action was official but he sued Van Niekerk in his personal capacity. Professor Van Niekerk adopted the view that because it had arisen out of an official action, Mr. Pelser could not sue personally and that the State could not be defamed. Appellate Division held that although an action for defamation had arisen out of an official action, the Minister could be defamed personally. In that case, although it was a personal action, the State paid Mr. Pelser&#x2019;s costs.</p>

<p>Now what happened in my case, Mr. Chairman, is that my telephone rang on Sunday night at 10 o&#x2019;clock. I picked up the telephone and someone by the name of Jeremy Gordon answered from the other side, or so he stated. He then told me that they were going to publish something that Dr. Rhoodie had said about me, which when he read it to me, I considered to be defamatory. I then said to him that I did not mind if he published it I said: &#x201C;You may publish that material, but you have a Press Union Code and a press union agreement with us to the effect that when you are not certain whether facts are true or not you will verify them and give the other side an opportunity of stating their case.&#x201D; I also said to him: &#x201C;I have notes. This matter is in respect of an interview that I had with a French journalist, a journalist who had been imposed on me by the then Department of Information, a person whom I normally would never have seen.&#x201D; As a matter of fact, I did not want to see him in any case. However, three calls were made from the department asking me to see this gentleman. I told this man over the &#x2019;phone that I had notes about the meeting. I said to him: &#x201C;If you want to be fair, just hold this over for one day and publish it on Tuesday morning. Give me an opportunity of telling you exactly what transpired there, but I need my notes to be able to give a proper answer to your question since you are asking me for comment.&#x201D; He realized the truth of that because he said: &#x201C;I will come back to you in a few minutes&#x2019; time and I will let you know what my editor says.&#x201D; He came back within five minutes and told me that his editor had said they were going to publish the material whether I commented or not. I went to court and applied for an interdict. It must be made quite clear that if it had not been defamatory <i>prima facie</i> the court would have sent me back home.</p>

<p>They would have said: &#x201C;No, there is nothing wrong with it. You can go back home.&#x201D; But the court granted me a temporary interdict. Subsequent to that, the court found that it was not defamatory but that was not the first finding of the court The first finding of the court was that it was <i>prima facie</i> defamatory. The matter then came up as to who was going to pay for it. I then told the State Attorney to give me the principles on which this matter was based because I was not going to decide this in my own case although I had decided this in the case of Mr. Pelser. This falls within the ordinary duties of my office. The principles are normally laid before me after a discussion with the Secretary or with the State Attorney. I then decide whether it falls within the principles or not and then I make a decision. However, in my own case I was not prepared to make a decision.</p>

<p>Ek het egter die voorlegging ontvang en ek sal dit tot die beskikking van die Opposisie stel as hulle dit wil h&#x00EA;. Ek dink dit is alleenlik billik dat ek &#x2019;n paar gedeeltes van hierdie voorlegging aanhaal. Dit lui soos volg&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">Artikel 3 van die Wet op die Staatsprokureur 1957 &#x2026;</block>

<p>Ek lees nou uit sy voorlegging&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">&#x2026; magtig die Staatsprokureur om prokureurswerk, ten behoewe van die Regering en ander owerheidsinstansies te doen en ook om tensy die Minister van Justisie anders gelas prokureurswerk te verrig in of in verband met enige aangeleentheid waarby die Regering hoewel geen party nie, belang het of betrokke is of in verband met &#x2019;n aangeleentheid waar dit volgens die oordeel van die Staatsprokureur of aan iemand wat op sy gesag handel, in die openbare belang is dat dit gedoen word.</block>

<p>Ek lees net gedeeltes van die voorlegging om <span class="col_639-640" refersTo="page_0322"/>die argument na sy logiese konsekwensies te bring. Ek haal weer aan&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">Waar &#x2019;n beampte weens &#x2019;n beweerde onregmatige daad wat uit sy ampspligte voortspruit aangespreek of aangekla word is dit moontlik dat die Staat as sy werkgewer ook aanspreeklik kan wees. Die ander oorweging is dat beamptes van die Staat en net so ook Ministers en uitvoerende funksionarisse van die Staat dikwels deur die vervulling van hul ampspligte blootgestel word aan belastering en ook aan &#x2019;n verhoogde risiko dat hulle een of ander vorm van aanspreeklikheid vir skadevergoeding kan opdoen.</block>

<p>Dan s&#x00EA; die Staatsprokureur, en ek haal aan&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">Amptenare en Ministers sal met baie min vrymoedigheid hulle take behartig indien hulle nie van sulke bystand verseker kan wees nie.</block>

<p>Hy s&#x00EA; voorts&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">Daar kan twee soorte regskoste hier ter sprake kom, die koste aangegaan deur die Staatsprokureur in die loop van sy hantering van die saak, en die koste van &#x2019;n teenparty wat ingevolge &#x2019;n bevel van &#x2019;n hof aan daardie party betaal moet word. Die praktyk is dat beide soorte regskoste in sulke tersaaklike gevalle betaal word uit Staatsfondse. Tesourie-instruksie 3308 sub. 4 bepaal dat in sulke gevalle die bedrag wat aan die eiser betaal moet word, sowel as die staatsprokureur se regskoste, teen staatsfondse in rekening gebring word, behalwe waar die beampte buite sy diensverband of die bestek van sy magtiging opgetree het of nie <i>bona fide</i> geglo het dat hy binne sy diensverband of die bestek van sy magtiging opgetree het nie. Alhoewel die hof uiteindelik bevind het dat die materiaal wat gepubliseer sou word nie lasterlik was nie, het dit op die oog af lasterlik voorgekom en het &#x2019;n hof inderdaad so bevind. In &#x2019;n mening wat voor die uitspraak maar na die aansoek om &#x2019;n interdik gedoen is, deur die staatsregsadviseurs uitgespreek is, het hulle tot die slotsom gekom dat die berig rakende die bandopname van die onderhoud met die joernalis wel lasterlik was.</block>

<p>Ek het toe &#x2019;n regsopinie aangevra. Ek haal verder aan&#x2014;</p>

<block name="quote">Die Hoofstaatsprokureur s&#x00EA; nadat hy die uitspraak bestudeer het, hy van mening was dat indien al die feite vooraf tot sy beskikking was, hy sou besluit het dat die Staatsprokureur vir die Minister moes optree en dat die Staat die koste dus sou moes dra. In di&#x00E9; verband wys hy daarop dat die onderhoud met die Franse joernalis plaasgevind het in die loop van die Minister se uitvoering van sy ampsplig en dat die geding voortgespruit het uit en verband gehou het met daardie uitvoering van die Minister se ampspligte.</block>

<p>I want to tell the hon. member&#x2014;I do not know why she mentioned this but she has and she is quite entitled to know it&#x2014;I was prepared in the ordinary course of my duties to take a decision on behalf of any of my colleagues who may have found themselves in the same situation. However, as far as my own case was concerned, I was not prepared to take a decision of that nature. I then went to the Cabinet with the matter. I am authorized by the Cabinet to say that the Cabinet agreed with what was placed before them by the State Attorney. In the circumstances they decided that this fell within that rule and that the State would pay the costs.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>The taxpayers in other words.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Who else did the hon. member think it would be?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I did not think of anybody else.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Would the hon. member like to take the risks in this job without any support?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I do not think I would go rushing off to court like that knowing how expensive lawyers are.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Die agb. lid het vir my gevra omtrent die Christelike Instituut Die posisie ten opsigte van die Christelike Instituut is soos volg. [Tussenwerpsel.] Wil die agb. lid na die beantwoording van haar vrae luister?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from><span class="col_641-642" refersTo="page_0323"/>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Sorry, I agree with you, it is not worth listening to.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Die agb. lid moenie oor die vloer van die Huis &#x2019;n bespreking voer nie.</p>

<p>Wat die Christelike Instituut betref, is daar met die besluit slegs oor een vaste eiendom moeilikheid ondervind wat die finale bereddering vertraag. Sodra daardie vaste eiendom se probleme uit die weg geruim is, sal ons kan voortgaan om die Christelike Instituut finaal te likwideer.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid het &#x2019;n vraag gestel ten opsigte van mev. Edelstein. Ek wil vir haar s&#x00EA; dat die finale verslag van die aangestelde komitee nog nie ter hand is nie. Ek wil terselfdertyd s&#x00EA; ek het die grootste simpatie met mev. Edelstein. Wat die Komitee ook al mag besluit, ek is van plan om die geval van mev. Edelstein wel na die Kabinet te verwys.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid het gevra wanneer die Cilliekommissie se werk klaar is. Die antwoord is wanneer Regter Cillie sy taak voltooi het.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>My word! It has been three years already.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Die agb. lid vir Waterkloof het gepraat oor die reg van privaatheid. Dit was &#x2019;n baie belangrike toespraak en ek sal wel aandag daaraan gee. Die agb. lid vir Brakpan het ook verwys na die kommissie oor veiligheidswetgewing. Daarop het ek reeds geantwoord. Die agb. lid vir Randburg het ook die mening uitgespreek dat &#x2019;n mens moet kyk of so &#x2019;n kommissie nie aangestel kan word nie. Ek het die Regering se standpunt gestel en ek het vir die agb. lid vir Randburg ges&#x00EA; dat ons nie halsstarrig is wat dit aanbetref nie. Ons sal daarna kyk.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid vir Eshowe het oor die Prokureur-generaal gepraat. Dit was vir my interessant om te sien dat die agb. lid vir Houghton hom kon kwaad kry, want hy is werklikheid so &#x2019;n groot heer. Hy het op &#x2019;n baie bedaarde manier en soos &#x2019;n ware heer vir haar ges&#x00EA;: Nou maak jy my kwaad.</p>

<p>Ek wil net na die geval van genl. Van den Berg verwys wat die Prokureur-generaal betref. Ek het al in die Volksraad ges&#x00EA; dat ek my met die besluit van die Prokureur-generaal vereenselwig nadat die Prokureurgeneraal ten volle aan my verslag gedoen het Ek kon nie anders nie, Meneer, en dit kom ook nou uit. Die publiek sal dit wel agterkom dat op daardie spesifieke stadium my oorweging in landsbelang was, dit was prim&#x00EA;r. Daar het &#x2019;n interessante stukkie debat plaasgevind, Meneer, wat u miskien sal onthou. Die agb. lid vir Houghton sal dit onthou want dit is sy wat die snedige opmerking daaroor gemaak het. Ek het in die loop van my argument ges&#x00EA; dat dit in elk geval twyfelagtig is of ons vir genl. Van den Berg kon aangekla het Ek het die punt gemaak dat die Erasmuskommissie op die 5de ten einde geloop het en dat genl. Van den Berg die volgende dag of die dag daarna sy uitlatings gemaak het. Die daaropvolgende dag is die kommissie se werksaamhede verleng. Ek het toe die punt geopper dat dit baie moontlik is dat die advokate die punt sou neem dat die Erasmuskommissie <i>de facto</i> op die 5de tot &#x2019;n einde gekom het en dat die hemuwing eintlik beteken dat die kommissie weer <i>de novo</i> begin het. Die agb. lid vir Houghton het my toe uitgelag, Meneer. Wat het nou in die Hooggeregshof gebeur? Waarop is hul beslissing gebaseer? Toe die Erasmus-kommissie vir &#x2019;n interdik gevra het, is hierdie selfde punt geargumenteer. Maar toe ek vir die agb. lid ges&#x00EA; het dat die advokate hierdie punt sou argumenteer, het sy my uitgelag. Ek herhaal, Meneer, dit is baie twyfelagtig of genl. Van den Berg in die omstandighede aangekla kon word.</p>

<p>The hon. member for Walmer wants the Attorneys-General to be appointed like the Auditor-General and to submit a report to Parliament. I want to say to the hon. member that I am sympathetic towards the idea because this has been a polemic for many, many years in South Africa. The hon. member will remember that right up to the day of the National Convention the Attorney-General was a member of the Cabinet. He used to come into Parliament and the Convention felt very strongly about it. The Convention wanted him right out of politics and they took him out of politics until I think it was in 1926 when the situation became unbearable because nobody wanted to have anything to do with the AG. Why should the Minister of Justice take more onerous duties on his shoulders than those he has? He has enough as it is. The Minister of Justice used to adopt the attitude that he was not responsible for the Attorney-General&#x2019;s decisions. In 1926 it was brought back by an <span class="col_643-644" refersTo="page_0324"/>amendment to the Act&#x2014;there was again to be parliamentary responsibility for the Attorney-General&#x2019;s actions. That was why in the case of the Gen. Van den Berg matter I took full responsibility. I told the Assembly at the time that it was my responsibility and that I had taken it. I said that the Attorney-General had exercised his discretion and that I was not going to get involved in his discretionary power, but that as far as Parliament was concerned, I took the responsibility for the Attorney-General because I had to try to explain to the House what his motivations were and to the best of my ability had to represent him in the House. This is something the hon. member for Walmer must not forget. If we take the Attorney-General away from the Ministry of Justice we are going to have a number of problems. The main problem will be that he will not have a voice in Parliament. He will have to go through one of the committees. Hon. members will not be able to discuss his decisions as they did in the case of Gen. Van den Berg where the Minister was asked to take the responsibility. This has been the polemic all along. Therefore, I am inclined to say that we must leave the Attorneys-General as they are because they have been doing good work for many, many years. Nobody has ever involved them in anything. I think on two occasions the actions of an Attorney-General were questioned in Parliament as it is the right of parliamentarians to do, but that only happened on two occasions over a period of about 50 years. Why change something that works well? This system is part and parcel of the administration of justice. There are promotions. The younger members of the Attorney-General&#x2019;s staff move up as members of the Department of Justice and eventually they become Attorneys-General. I do not think we should try to change a system that is working very well. That is my answer to the hon. member for Walmer.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#aronson">

<from>Mr. <person refersTo="hansard_za">T. ARONSON</person>:</from>

<p>May I ask the hon. the Minister a question? I actually raised the matter in 1978 before the Van den Berg case. I also asked the hon. the Minister whether he would not consider discussing the matter with the Secretary for Justice, the Attorneys-General concerned and other interested parties. That is all I am asking the hon. the Minister.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>I shall do so. I know, Sir, that when I say things I sometimes sound very categorical, but I do not mean to be quite as categorical as I sound. I shall certainly discuss with the departments concerned the points the hon. member has raised to see whether they have any ideas on this particular matter.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid vir Potgietersms het die punt gemaak&#x2014;ek dink dit is iets wat die agb. lid vir Walmer kan onthou&#x2014;hy is reg en ek stem met hom saam, dat as ons die voorstel van die agb. lid vir Walmer sou aanvaar elke afdeling met &#x2019;n soortgelyke versoek sou kom, m.a.w. die Meester van die Hooggeregshof se afdeling sal dan ook vra dat hulle weggeneem moet word van die beheer van die Staatsdienskommissie. Dit kan baie probleme bring.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid vir Umhlatuzana het oor die loopbane van Indi&#x00EB;rs en Kleurlinge uitgewei. Dit was &#x2019;n baie interessante toespraak en ek is baie dankbaar dat hy hierdie baie belangrike aspek van Justisie onder die aandag van agb. lede gebring het.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid vir Johannesburg-Noord het &#x2019;n baie interessante toespraak gelewer oor intermedi&#x00EA;re howe. Ek en die agb. lid vir Johannesburg-Noord het vir baie jare &#x2019;n assosiasie met mekaar gehad, veral as mede-Nasionaliste en u kan wel begryp dat ons we&#x00EB; nou uitmekaar gegaan het. Ek wil egter aan die agb. lid s&#x00EA; dat ek sy goeie trou aanvaar. Wanneer hy oor di&#x00E9; dinge praat waarvan hy werklik kennis het, dan is sy toesprake op hul beste. Dit is maar die geval met ons almal. In hierdie geval. het hy dan ook &#x2019;n goeie toespraak gemaak. &#x2019;n Mens kon hoor dat hy iets van hierdie dinge weet. Ek wil aan hom die versekering gee dat ek sy gedagtes volledig opgeskryf het en dat ek hulle weer sal nagaan. Wanneer die intermedi&#x00EA;re howe uiteindelik tot stand kom, sal ons kyk hoeveel van hierdie baie vrugbare gedagtes bruikbaar is.</p>

<p>Dieselfde geld vir die agb. lid vir Mosselbaai. Hy het ook oor hierdie saak gepraat en dit was net so interessant en ook baie vmgbaar. Dieselfde geld vir die laaste agb. lid wat gepraat het, nl. die agb. lid vir Oos-Londen-Stad. Hy het oor die administratiewe reg gepraat. Dit is almal gedagtes wat met vrug verwerk kan word wanneer ons uiteindelik hierdie sake debatteer.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid vir Newton Park het die punt <span class="col_645-646" refersTo="page_0325"/>geopper dat waar ons die doodstraf vir moord het, ons nie ook moet oorweeg om in die geval van verkragtings verpligte doodstraf op te l&#x00EA; nie? Ek wil onmiddellik s&#x00EA; dat daardie gedagte werklik baie ernstige oorweging verdien. Ek het na die syfers van verkragtings gekyk, en wat my hinder is dat in een jaar daar oor die 4 000 verkragtings was. Mnr. die Voorsitter, wat my betref, wil ek s&#x00EA; dat nadat ek geluister het na die toespraak van die agb. lid vir Newton Park, ek as eerste stap van plan is om met die Departement van Gevangenisse te onderhandel om te sien of ons nie parool heeltemal vir verkragtings moet uitsluit nie. Mense wat vir verkragting gevonnis is, sal dan glad nie op parool kan uitkom nie. Dit is die eerste ding wat ek wil doen en die tweede ding is dat ek die voorstel van die agb. lid baie ernstig sal oorweeg. Ek dink &#x2019;n vrou is daarop geregtig dat geen man iets aan haar moet doen waartoe sy nie gewillig is nie. Ek dink onwilligheid aan die kant van &#x2019;n vrou behoort genoeg te wees om enige man tot stilstand te bring. Ek is van mening dat vir verkragters verpligte doodstraf miskien die aangewese ding is. Ek weet nie hoe die agb. lid vir Houghton daaroor voel nie.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I am against capital punishment.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Wat my betref, Meneer, as &#x2019;n mens dit eers verpligtend gemaak het&#x2026;</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Send people to gaol for longer periods.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>&#x2026; kan &#x2019;n mens daarna kyk of daar omstandighede is waarom die doodstraf nie uitgevoer moet word nie. Maar dit is absoluut noodsaaklik &#x2026;</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#langley">

<from>Mr. <person refersTo="hansard_za">T. LANGLEY</person>:</from>

<p>[Inaudible.]</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Why, don&#x2019;t you like it?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Dit is absoluut noodsaaklik in Suid-Afrika vir al ons mense, vir alle bevolkingsgroepe dat hulle die gevoel moet kry dat hulle vroumense beveilig is en ek sal seer sekerlik alles in my vermo&#x00EB; doen om ons vrouens die gevoel van veiligheid weer te laat geniet.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>You are not perhaps suggesting castration, are you?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Ons sal hierdie voorstel van &#x2019;n doodstraf na die permanente strafhervormingskomitee verwys.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>He was suggesting castration, that was the gist of his remarks.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#voorsitter">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">VOORSITTER</person>:</from>

<p>Orde!</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>&#x2026; en ons sal sien of die permanente strafhervormingskomitee nie vir ons al die moeilikhede kan nagaan nie. [Tussenwerpsel.]</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#voorsitter">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">VOORSITTER</person>:</from>

<p>Orde! Die agb. lid praat nou oor die vloer met die agb. lid vir Houghton. As hulle &#x2019;n privaatgesprek wil hou moet hulle in die gang gaan staan.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Die agb. lid vir Oos-Londen-Noord en die agb. lid vir Algoabaai het albei gevra dat internasionale hotellisensies outomaties hernieu moet word. Hierop is my antwoord dat ek nie bereid is om dit te doen nie, en ek sal vir die agb. lede s&#x00EA; hoekom. Ek hoop die agb. lid vir Algoabaai, vir wie ek baie respek het wat hierdie dinge betref, sal my motivering verstaan. Hierdie is &#x2019;n baie sensitiewe area; dit is &#x2019;n verhoudingsarea en die re&#x00EB;ls en regulasies en die ooreenkomste wat met die hoteliers aangegaan word moet van so &#x2019;n aard wees dat hulle uitvoerbaar is. My ervaring is dat as jy vir &#x2019;n persoon s&#x00EA; dat hy elke jaar aansoek moet doen, is hy daaraan gedagtig. Hy besef dat hy hom by die re&#x00EB;ls moet hou want sy lisensie sal nie outomaties hernieu word nie. Die agb. lid moet my motivering in gedagte hou.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#conradie">

<from>Mnr. <person refersTo="hansard_za">F. D. CONRADIE</person>:</from>

<p>Ja, maar kan die voorreg van outomatiese hernuwing nie mettertyd verdien word nie, byvoorbeeld as &#x2019;n applikant vir drie of vier jaar agtereenvolgens met sy aansoek geslaag het nie?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Dit is &#x2019;n ander voorstel wat &#x2019;n mens wel kan oorweeg; ek sal dit beslis oorweeg. Met ander woorde, diegene wat geen moeilikhede deur die loop van &#x2019;n paar jaar veroorsaak nie, se lisensies kan outomaties hernieu word. Maar my ervaring <span class="col_647-648" refersTo="page_0326"/>is dat hierdie hernuwings versigtigheid meebring op &#x2019;n area wat baie sensitief is en waar versigtigheid nodig is. Dit geld veral as &#x2019;n mens in gedagte hou dat hierdie mense in besigheid staan om geld te maak en jy kan besef dat daar somtyds &#x2019;n gebrek aan die nodige versigtigheid is.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid vir Musgrave het ook na die internasionale lisensies verwys, maar hy het dit vanuit &#x2019;n ander oogpunt benader. Hy vra bv: &#x201E;Waarom is 15% van die beddens in &#x2019;n hotel vir Nie-blankes gereserveer?&#x201D; Ek kan vir hom s&#x00EA; dat nie 2% van die Nieblanke beddens opgeneem word nie. Ons het hierdie voorwaarde ingevoeg omdat ons nie wou gehad het dat in die geval van hotelle in Blanke groepsgebiede&#x2014;m.a.w. Blanke hotelle&#x2014;ons skielik mag vind dat daar meer Swart mense na die hotelle kom as Blankes nie. Daardeur sal ons rassewrywing kry, presies dit wat ons nie wil h&#x00EA; nie. Daarom het ons ges&#x00EA; dat ons in die Blanke groepsgebied stadig moet gaan; ons moet &#x2019;n persentasie neerl&#x00EA; waar Blankes die beddens kan beset. Dit is niks meer as dit nie. Die hoteliers is ook daarvan bewus, Meneer, want die Swart mense beset nie meer as omtrent 2%&#x2014;ek dink dit is die hoogste syfer&#x2014;van die bedde in die hotelle nie.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#malcomess">

<from>Mr. <person refersTo="hansard_za">D. J. N. MALCOMESS</person>:</from>

<p>Why have it in at all then if that is the case; why do you not withdraw it?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>Die <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Meneer, ek vind dit snaaks dat &#x2019;n man somaar in &#x2019;n debat kan inkom en s&#x00EA;: &#x201E;If that is the case, why do you not withdraw it?&#x201D; Ek gee hom nou my hele motivering. Ons is altyd besig om na hierdie aspekte te kyk om te sien of ons moet terugtrek, meer moet toepas, of wat ons ook al moet doen. Ons sal daarna kyk, Meneer. Ons kyk gedurig na die toestaan van dranklisensies omdat ons baie begerig is dat hierdie hele situasie sonder enige insidente moet verloop. Tot dusver was ons baie gelukkig. Wat as &#x2019;n eksperiment begin het, het sedertdien geblyk &#x2019;n baie suksesvolle eksperiment te wees.</p>

<p>Die benadering van die agb. lid vir Musgrave is egter anders. Waar ons probeer om aan &#x2019;n behoefte te voldoen wil hy aan &#x2019;n sekere filosofie voldoen. Hy soek veelrassigheid bloot om veelrassigheid te h&#x00EA; en al die regulasies en al die voorwaardes is vir hom uit die bose; hy wil &#x2019;n totale ge&#x00EF;ntegreerde gemeenskap h&#x00EA;. Sy gedagtes loop so; hy kan nie verstaan dat ons aan die werklike behoeftes van die Suid-Afrikaanse samelewing wil voldoen nie. Daarom het ons dit soos ons dit het, en nie soos hy dit graag wil h&#x00EA; nie.</p>

<p>Die agb. lid vir Verwoerdburg het baie interessante feite oor inperkings genoem en &#x2019;n besondere mooi toespraak gemaak. Die agb. lede vir Durban-Noord, Tuine, Hillbrow, Durbanville en Groenpunt het ek reeds geantwoord. Ek dank u, mnr. die Voorsitter.</p>

<p>Begrotingspos goedgekeur.</p>

<p>Die Komitee gaan om 15h52 uiteen.</p>

</speech>

</debateSection>

<debateSection name="#appropriation_bill">

<heading><span class="col_649-650" refersTo="page_0327"/>APPROPRIATION BILL</heading>

<p>Revenue Vote No. 23.&#x2014;&#x201C;Police&#x201D;:</p>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Mr. Chairman, may I ask the privilege of the half-hour?</p>

<p>The report of the Commissioner of the S.A. Police provides some interesting statistics and I am sure that penologists and criminologists and sociologists will all find it very useful indeed. The crime rate which is depicted in this report is pretty horrifying and I am referring now only to serious crimes of violence. There were close on 6 000 cases of murder reported in the year under review, i.e. July 1977 to June 1978. In regard to assault with intent to do serious bodily harm, the figures show over 131 000 cases; there were over 15 000 cases of rape&#x2014;for the hon. member who is particularly interested in that crime&#x2014;there were 59 000 cases relating to the security of the state and good order, and 4 000 cases of robbery with aggravating circumstances. There were also over 400 000 infringements of the law; in fact over 426 000, if one includes taxation offences which actually came to court, and offences in respect of curfew regulations, the registration and production of documents under the Urban Areas Act and for trespass.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister_of_police">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER OF POLICE</person>:</from>

<p>How many were there?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>There were about 426 000 of these statutory infringements of the law, all revolving round influx control and the pass laws, if one includes taxation cases. As I have said <i>ad nauseam</i> in the House, all these statutory infringements cause enormous resentment among Blacks and engenders chronic hostility of Black people against the Police Force who have the unenviable job of enforcing these laws and of arresting people. I must say at once that I cannot wait for the day when some genius works out how to implement the proposals of the Riekert Commission; in other words, to do away with pass law infringements whilst still continuing to retain influx control, because those are really, in essence, the recommendations of the Riekert Commission. But in the meantime, until some genius does work out this method, I would ask that the hon. the Minister ensure that the instructions that are given to the police about first warning people before they arrest them and about not arresting people who are employed for mere non-production of documents, be enforced most strictly. I can tell the hon. the Minister that thousands of people still get arrested for the nonproduction of documents even though they are employed. Indeed, I had one glaring case not too long ago of an old lady who lives in my constituency who &#x2019;phoned me to say that the police had raided her premises and had taken her only domestic employee from his gardening job, had assaulted him and had arrested him for non-production of documents, although she in fact had produced the pass, the F-card of employment, and so on.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister_of_police">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER OF POLICE</person>:</from>

<p>A policeman?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Her employee identified a policeman at the Norwood Police Station. Eventually a charge was laid and it came to court. I must tell the hon. the Minister that the investigating officer came from the same police station. The whole case was conducted in a very haphazard way and in the end the accused was discharged. There is no doubt that this sort of thing is still going on. Frequently I get complaints from people in my constituency of police vans swooping down on the northern suburbs of Johannesburg and picking up people under curfew regulations who are simply visiting friends or else they pick them up because they do not happen to have their passes with them. I know that the hon. the Minister is concerned about this and I ask him to see that the instructions will now be carried out meticulously because up till now that has not been the case.</p>

<p>I believe that the whole climate of race relations in South Africa would change instantly if pass laws were abolished and Black South Africans could move freely around the country like any other citizen. It is the greatest cause of racial friction in this country and I believe it would disappear overnight if pass laws were to go. What is more, the police could devote themselves to solving real crime, to preventing real crime and to arresting real criminals. There is more than enough of that to keep the police very busy indeed as the report shows and as a reply to a question which I put to the hon. the <span class="col_651-652" refersTo="page_0328"/>Minister this session, also shows. In Soweto alone, for example, there were 368 cases of murder reported between July 1977 and June 1978. That is more than one a day. There were 1 188 cases of rape, 7 462 cases of assault with intent to commit grievous bodily harm and 3 802 cases of robbery, a grand total of nearly 13 000 cases of serious crime in Soweto in one year alone of which more than half were unsolved. The point I want to make is that it is to this sort of case that the police should be devoting their attention. In the first three months of this year there was a report in the Press that over 180 people had already been murdered in Soweto.</p>

<p>I also think it would be a very good thing if the hon. the Minister would study the trends in other countries&#x2014;let us keep my record on this absolutely straight&#x2014;and investigate the tendency there to consider the possession of marijuana for personal use as a misdemean-our rather than a crime. Last year there were 24 000 reported cases concerning the use of dagga which were brought before the courts. Many hundreds, if not thousands, were added to the prison population as a result of this.</p>

<p>There are other crimes which I believe the police should be relieved of investigating; for example, Immorality Act cases, which cause such anguish to the people concerned and to their families and which so often result in the very worst sort of publicity abroad. There were 363 such cases between July 1977 and June 1978 resulting in 295 persons being charged. The hon. the Minister might also look into the whole question of the enthusiasm with which the police apparently pursue some of the reported offences under the Immorality Act I refer of course to the case of the young woman in Pretoria who appeared to have been invaded by a veritable platoon of police in the middle of the night.</p>

<p>I am very glad to learn from an article in the newspaper that camouflage uniforms are no longer going to be used by the riot police, according to the Chief of the riot police in Soweto. As the hon. the Minister knows, I took the strongest exception to the use of camouflage uniform because it gave the impression that the police were at war with the residents of Soweto, which engendered further hostility. I am very glad to hear that that is no longer going to be the case.</p>

<p>I come now to the issue which always infuriates the hon. the Minister and perhaps he should calm himself down with a glass of water. It is however something which I believe is of the greatest importance because it profoundly affects the relationship between the police and the community. I am referring now to police violence.</p>

<p>I want to commence with the usual obvious comment&#x2014;I have to do this every time; it does not make any difference but I will do so again&#x2014;that I am not seeking to remove the means of self-protection from the police who have to do dangerous jobs involving dangerous criminals but I do believe that there have been far too many cases where the police have been involved in violent action against the public. Firstly, I cannot accept that last year it was necessary for the police to shoot dead 132 adults and 8 juveniles and to wound 336 adults and 32 juveniles who were attempting to avoid arrest. The lives of the police could not have been jeopardized by people who were evading arrest. It would surely be interesting to have an analysis made of the crimes these people were suspected of committing that caused the police, instead either of letting them escape or attempting to tackle them and capture them actually to draw their fire-arms and shoot such people.</p>

<p>The hon. the Minister has mentioned the amounts paid out to members of the public for assault and unlawful arrest. He mentioned this under the previous Vote.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister_of_police">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER OF POLICE</person>:</from>

<p>You asked for it under the previous Vote.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Yes, but it is a matter that falls under both Votes, unfortunately. It was a total of over R300 000 in three years, which is an increasing amount and a cause for concern. By the way, if members think that this increase was due to the 2% years of unrest and turmoil in the townships from June 1976 onwards, I have to remind them that the Indemnity Act of 1977 took care of that. No doubt the hon. the Minister hopes that now that the Police Amendment Act has been passed, fewer cases of police violence will in future be reported in the Press. I sincerely hope that will not be the case but I fear very much that it is going to be the case as a result of the passing of that Act.</p>

<p>I wonder if it has ever occurred to the hon. the Minister that the truculent attitude that he has adopted towards me year after year when <span class="col_653-654" refersTo="page_0329"/>I have raised these matters may have been taken as tacit condonation of their actions by the police? I have no doubt that if the hon. the Minister&#x2019;s attitude changed and if severe action was promised against the police for the unnecessary use of fire-arms or assaults against the public, the figures would drop dramatically, instead of which we find cases in which the police have been retained in the Force despite the fact that some of them have actually been convicted of offences such as assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm. To support my contention in this regard I wish to say that it is no mere coincidence that since the Biko death in detention on 12 September 1977 and the ensuing furore there has been only one further death in detention and that was during the same time as the Biko inquest. Fortunately, there have been none since then although there were a lot of people in detention under section 6 throughout 1978. Indeed, last May there were 168 under section 6 and 111 under section 12(b) of the Internal Security Act At present 71 people are being held under section 6. I do not ascribe, as the hon. the Minister appears to do, the welcome absence of fatalities only to the two watchdogs whom he appointed, namely, Messrs. Van den Bergh and Mouton, the one for the Cape and the Orange Free State and the other for the Transvaal and Natal. [Interjections.] The impression given was that that was one of the major reasons. [Interjections.] Well, then, perhaps the hon. the Minister can tell me why there have been no more deaths in detention? Is it just a coincidence?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister_of_police">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER OF POLICE</person>:</from>

<p>How should I know? You are asking me a negative question.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I will tell the hon. the Minister why. I certainly do not ascribe it either to the forthnightly visits by magistrates to section 6 detainees, to which both the hon. the Minister and the hon. member for Verwoerdburg attached so much importance. I want to remind the hon. the Minister and that hon. member that section 6 detainees are always visited by magistrates fortnightly, and yet there were 35 deaths in detention under section 6. Biko was visited by a magistrate. Peter Jones, who was arrested together with Biko, and who spent 17 months in jail, 4&#x00BD; months of which were under section 6, was visited by a magistrate every fortnight. I want to tell the hon. the Minister and the hon. member for Verwoerdburg that there&#x2014;I hope the hon. the Minister will listen to this when he has collected his sweeties&#x2014;we could have had another Biko case, but for the grace of God.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Why?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I will tell the hon. the Minister why. The manner in which this man was treated when he was in detention at the Algoa Park police station is nothing short of disgraceful. Yet magistrates visited him from the 1st September &#x2026;</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Who are you talking about?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I am talking of Peter Jones, the man who was arrested together with Biko in August and who was detained at the Algoa Park police station from 19 August until 1 November under section 6; he was then detained at the Kinkelbos police station for a further period under section 6, and then ultimately spent about a year under section 10 at Grahamstown prison. While he was at Algoa Park police station he was kept naked the entire time. He was given one blanket and one bedroll. He was not allowed for the first two months to bath, he was kept in a locked cell for the entire period and he was not allowed any exercise. The point that I am trying to make is that the magistrate visited him&#x2014;several magistrates, in fact, almost every time a different magistrate&#x2014;and yet there was no complaint made about the manner in which this man was being held. The magistrates who visited him must also have seen injuries that were inflicted on this man during the interrogations to which he was subjected at all hours of the day and night, when he was taken by the security police &#x201C;bully-boys&#x201D;, at Sanlam Building.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Where did you see those injuries?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>I must tell the hon. the Minister that all this is on affidavit.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Affidavit by whom?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from><span class="col_655-656" refersTo="page_0330"/>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Naturally by the man himself.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>By Mr. Jones?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>By whom else?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Did he give it to the magistrate?</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>When a man is held under section 6 he does not have very much opportunity of doing any of these things.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#minister">

<from>The <person refersTo="hansard_za">MINISTER</person>:</from>

<p>Oh, come on.</p>

</speech>

<speech by="#suzman">

<from>Mrs. <person refersTo="hansard_za">H. SUZMAN</person>:</from>

<p>Does the hon. the Minister not think that these things should be seen by the magistrate? If a man is being kept naked, should the magistrate not observe this? Is this not an incredible state of affairs?</p>

</speech>
